title: Gold Rush Heritage Trail
subtitle: From Empire Mine to Malakoff Diggins
description: Follow the story of gold through Nevada County. From the deepest mines to the largest hydraulic diggings, each stop connects to the next through 170 years of history.

stops.note: One of the oldest, deepest, richest gold mines in California. 367 miles of underground tunnels produced over $120M in gold from 1850 to 1957.
stops.connector: The mine's superintendent needed a home befitting the operation's grandeur...

stops.note: 1905 mansion designed by Julia Morgan for mine superintendent A.D. Foote.
stops.connector: Foote's greatest engineering feat wasn't the house - it was the powerhouse below...

stops.note: World's largest Pelton wheel, 30 feet in diameter. Built by Foote in 1895, the first complete water-powered compressed air plant of its kind.
stops.connector: The Pelton wheel was invented just up the road...

stops.note: Founded 1856. The Pelton waterwheel was developed and manufactured here in 1878. The double-cupped bucket design revolutionized water power worldwide.
stops.connector: Next door, the oldest theatre on the West Coast...

stops.note: Opened September 11, 1865. Mark Twain, Emma Nevada, and Jack London all performed here. Still operating after 160 years.
stops.connector: West of the Gold Country towns, a republic once stood...

stops.note: Founded 1849. In 1850, the town seceded from the United States to form the Great Republic of Rough and Ready. The rebellion lasted less than three months.
stops.connector: North into the Ridge, miners built a school for their children...

stops.note: Built by miners in 1875 on the San Juan Ridge. Now hosts artists, film screenings, poetry readings, and the Sierra Storytelling Festival.
stops.connector: Further into the ridge, the scars of ambition...

stops.note: The world's largest hydraulic gold mining operation. High-pressure water cannons carved away entire mountainsides, leading to one of America's first environmental protection laws.

title: Highway 40: The Overland Trail
subtitle: Donner Summit to Truckee's Commercial Row
description: The most storied mountain crossing in American history. Emigrants, railroads, and highways all funneled through this pass. Every mile holds a monument to someone who tried to get over the Sierra.

stops.note: Retaining walls built by Chinese railroad workers in the 1860s. Hand-cut granite, still standing after 160 years of Sierra winters.
stops.connector: Just below the wall, the earliest travelers left their mark...

stops.note: The Donner Summit Bridge and nearby petroglyphs — some carved over 1,000 years ago by the Washoe people. The oldest human traces at the pass.
stops.connector: The first wagons crossed here in 1844, a year before the Donner Party...

stops.note: The Stephens-Townsend-Murphy party crossed here in November 1844 — the first wagons over the Sierra Nevada. They made it. The party that followed them did not.
stops.connector: A mile below the pass, the story turns dark...

stops.note: The Donner Party was stranded here through the winter of 1846-47. Of 87 emigrants, 48 survived. The 22-foot Pioneer Monument marks the depth of that winter's snow.
stops.connector: The museum at the park tells the full story...

stops.note: Inside Donner Memorial State Park. Chronicles the full arc of Sierra emigration — Washoe, wagon trains, railroad, and highway.
stops.connector: The railroad that finally tamed the pass ran straight through town...

stops.note: Truckee was a critical supply point for the transcontinental railroad. Theodore Judah surveyed this route. Chinese workers built it.
stops.connector: The railroad made Truckee a town, and that town still stands...

stops.note: Truckee's Brickelltown Historic District. Built in the 1870s after fire leveled the wooden originals. The saloons, hotels, and shops that served the railroad era.

title: Highway 20: The Yuba Divide
subtitle: Nevada City to the Town of Washington
description: East from Nevada City, Highway 20 climbs into increasingly wild country. Gold towns gave way to timber camps, then to near-ghost towns clinging to the canyon walls of the South Yuba River.

stops.note: The South Yuba Canal Company office in Nevada City. Built 1855. The canal system delivered water to hydraulic mines across the county — 700 miles of ditches carved into the Sierra.
stops.connector: The water they channeled powered the mines, but it also destroyed...

stops.note: The longest single-span covered bridge in the world when built in 1862. 233 feet across the South Yuba River. Still standing.
stops.connector: Past the bridge, the road narrows and the canyon deepens...

stops.note: Bedrock mortar holes used by the Nisenan people for thousands of years before the Gold Rush. A reminder that this land was home long before it was a highway.
stops.connector: The Nisenan traded along these same ridgelines...

stops.note: Built 1875 on the San Juan Ridge. The miners' children learned to read here. Now it's the cultural heart of the Ridge — poetry, film, storytelling.
stops.connector: Further east, the towns get smaller and the history gets stranger...

stops.note: Population: handful. Founded during the Gold Rush, nearly abandoned, then reborn as a quiet outpost. The Washington Hotel has been serving travelers since the 1850s.
stops.connector: The hotel is the town's anchor...

stops.note: One of California's oldest continuously operating hotels. Wedged into the South Yuba canyon, it's the last stop before the road drops into the river gorge.

title: Highway 49: The Arts Trail
subtitle: Grass Valley to Nevada City's Creative Core
description: Highway 49 connects two towns that transformed from mining camps into one of California's densest concentrations of working artists, theaters, and galleries. The gold is gone. What replaced it is better.

stops.note: Grass Valley's anchor arts venue. Gallery, stage, and the hub of the Fall Colors Open Studio Tour that opens 100+ artist studios across the county each October.
stops.connector: A few blocks north, the town's oldest building found new purpose...

stops.note: A 19th-century industrial foundry reborn as a cultural center. Concerts, theater, festivals, weddings. The building where they forged Pelton wheels now forges community.
stops.connector: Right next door, Mark Twain once took the stage...

stops.note: The oldest original-use theater building in California. Home to the Nevada City Film Festival, Wild & Scenic Film Festival, and more live performance per square foot than anywhere in the Sierra.
stops.connector: Across the street, another stage...

stops.note: Intimate black-box theater producing original plays, comedy, and community theater since 1980. Nevada City's living room stage.
stops.connector: Up Broad Street, the town's history is on display...

stops.note: Nevada City's 1861 firehouse, now a museum housing Donner Party artifacts, Nisenan baskets, and rotating exhibits on local history and art.
stops.connector: Down the hill, the filmmakers and the bartenders share a wall...

stops.note: Herbal lounge, gallery, and performance space. Live music, open mic, art shows, and craft mocktails. Nevada City's answer to the question: what if a gallery served kava?
stops.connector: Further south, a different kind of theater...

stops.note: Small-batch cinema. Independent and art-house films in an intimate setting. The kind of theater where the projectionist knows your name.

title: Poetry & Performance Circuit
subtitle: Where Nevada County Goes to Listen
description: Spoken word, live theater, film festivals, and a poetry festival that draws writers from across the West. Nevada County has more performance venues per capita than most cities ten times its size.

stops.note: The oldest theater in California. Mark Twain performed here in 1866. The Wild & Scenic Environmental Film Festival fills it every January.
stops.connector: The tradition of live performance spread next door...

stops.note: From industrial forge to cultural forge. The main stage hosts Music in the Mountains, the Artisans Festival, and hundreds of concerts a year.
stops.connector: Across town, the intimate stages...

stops.note: Community theater at its best. Original productions, improv nights, and the kind of scrappy creativity that only happens in a 99-seat house.
stops.connector: Down the hill, poetry and kava...

stops.note: Open mic nights, poetry slams, and acoustic sets in an herbal lounge. The unofficial living room of Nevada City's spoken-word scene.
stops.connector: The festival that ties it all together...

stops.note: The Sierra Poetry Festival — drawing poets from across the western states. Workshops, readings, and the kind of deep attention that poetry demands.
stops.connector: Up on the Ridge, the oldest venue of them all...

stops.note: The Sierra Storytelling Festival happens here. Built by miners in 1875, now the most unlikely and perfect poetry venue in the county.
stops.connector: Across the summit, Truckee has its own literary outpost...

stops.note: Truckee's independent bookstore and performance space. Author readings, book clubs, and community gatherings. Proof that the literary spirit crosses the Donner Pass.

title: Victorian Downtown Heritage
subtitle: Gold Rush Architecture & Historic Districts
description: Walk through the grand Victorian era of Grass Valley and Nevada City. From opulent mansions to historic hotels, each building tells the story of Gold Rush wealth reinvested in community.

stops.note: An 1891 Victorian mansion, meticulously restored. Built during the height of Gold Rush prosperity, this Queen Anne home embodies the optimism of a boom town.
stops.connector: A few blocks away, another Victorian treasure welcomes travelers...

stops.note: A Victorian-era guest inn at 304 Church Street. The kind of place where you half-expect to see horse-drawn carriages out front.
stops.connector: Downtown, a hotel has been welcoming visitors since 1851...

stops.note: The oldest continuously operating hotel in California's Mother Lode. Mark Twain, Ulysses S. Grant, and four U.S. presidents have stayed here.
stops.connector: Across the county, Nevada City's own historic hotel stands...

stops.note: Built in 1856 at 211 Broad Street. Nevada City's answer to The Holbrooke — still serving travelers after 170 years.
stops.connector: The preservation of these stories is no accident...

stops.note: Nevada County Historical Society's archives. Over 160,000 photographs, documents, and artifacts preserving the region's Victorian heritage.
stops.connector: That preservation spirit lives on in community spaces...

stops.note: Grass Valley's cultural hub at 314 West Main. A historic building transformed into gallery and performance space — Victorian bones, contemporary purpose.
stops.connector: Nevada City's oldest public building tells a different story...

stops.note: Built in 1861 to protect the town's wooden Victorian buildings from fire. Now houses a museum of Donner Party artifacts and local history.
stops.connector: The best way to see it all is on foot...

stops.asset: Walking Tour of Historic Grass Valley: self guided and guided
stops.note: Self-guided or docent-led tours through Grass Valley's Victorian district. Every block holds another architectural gem.
stops.connector: Nevada City offers its own perspective...

stops.asset: Walking Tour of Nevada City Trees
stops.note: A walking tour that traces Nevada City's historic trees — many planted during the Victorian era, now towering witnesses to 150 years of history.
stops.connector: Even the shops reflect the era...

stops.note: Located in Nevada City's historic Searls Avenue district. A small business in a Victorian storefront — commerce and preservation in harmony.

title: Foothills Flavor Trail
subtitle: Wine Country & Farm-to-Table Dining
description: Savor the Sierra foothills' culinary renaissance. Visit award-winning wineries, taste boutique vintages, and dine at restaurants showcasing local ingredients and old-world craftsmanship.

stops.note: Estate winery at 19698 View Forever Lane. Family-owned since 2001, producing Italian-style reds from Sierra foothill grapes.
stops.connector: Their downtown tasting room brings the vineyard to Main Street...

stops.note: Downtown Grass Valley tasting room at 128 Mill Street. Taste the estate wines without driving to the vineyard.
stops.connector: Across town, another estate winery beckons...

stops.note: Estate winery at 11179 Gibson Drive. Small-batch vintages from hillside vineyards at 2,600 feet elevation.
stops.connector: They also have a downtown outpost...

stops.note: Downtown tasting room at 124 West Main. Sierra Starr's wines in the heart of historic Grass Valley.
stops.connector: Further into the hills, a boutique producer awaits...

stops.note: Boutique winery at 10024 Linnet Lane. Intimate tastings, small production, hillside vineyards.
stops.connector: Nevada City has its own wine scene...

stops.note: Downtown winery at 321 Spring Street. Nevada City's answer to Napa — minus the traffic, plus the Gold Rush charm.
stops.connector: For something truly unique, head to the hills...

stops.note: Ultra-boutique non-traditional blends at 13028 Jones Bar Road. Experimental winemaking in a historic barn. Small batches, big ideas.
stops.connector: They opened a downtown tasting room for easier access...

stops.note: Downtown Grass Valley tasting room at 163 Mill Street. Taste the experimental vintages without the drive into the backcountry.
stops.connector: After the wine, the food...

stops.note: Farm-to-table dining at 135 Argall Way, Nevada City. Local ingredients, seasonal menus, and art on the walls. The foothills food philosophy in one room.
stops.connector: Grass Valley's culinary flagship...

stops.note: Upscale dining at 134 Mill Street. The kind of meal that makes you forget you're in a Gold Rush town — then reminds you why that history matters.

title: Gallery & Studio Loop
subtitle: Artist Studios & Creative Cooperatives
description: Discover Nevada County's thriving independent art scene. Visit working studios, artist-run galleries, and creative cooperatives where painters, printmakers, and sculptors create and exhibit side by side.

stops.note: Artist cooperative at 113 Mill Street. Twenty-plus working artists sharing space, exhibiting together, and running the gallery themselves.
stops.connector: Nearby, the community's anchor arts venue...

stops.note: Gallery at the Center for the Arts, 314 West Main. Rotating exhibits, open studios, and the hub of the annual Fall Colors Open Studio Tour each October.
stops.connector: Out Idaho Maryland Road, a collective of studios...

stops.note: Artist studios collective at 940 Idaho Maryland Road. Working artists in shared space — watch them create, see works in progress.
stops.connector: Further up the road, art meets nature...

stops.note: Gallery with outdoor amphitheater at 290 Sierra College Drive. Art indoors, performances under the pines.
stops.connector: Back toward town, a contemporary gallery...

stops.note: Contemporary art gallery at 342 Idaho Maryland Road. Clean lines, modern works, Sierra light through big windows.
stops.connector: A working artist's home and studio...

stops.note: Artist studio and home at 328 South Church Street. A printmaking studio where the artist lives and works — art and life inseparable.
stops.connector: Another working studio south of town...

stops.note: Artist workspace at 760 South Auburn Street. A place where making happens — paint, clay, wood, metal.
stops.connector: In Nevada City, the historic foundry turned arts hub...

stops.note: Historic foundry turned cultural center at 325 Spring Street. Where they once forged Pelton wheels, artists now forge community.
stops.connector: Across the street, a fine arts gallery...

stops.note: Fine arts gallery at 225 Broad Street. Paintings, sculpture, and works that reflect the beauty of the Sierra foothills.
stops.connector: Further up Broad Street, contemporary voices...

stops.note: Contemporary gallery at 408 Broad Street. Emerging artists, established names, and everything in between.

title: Nature & Trails Explorer
subtitle: State Parks & Wilderness Trails
description: Immerse yourself in pristine Sierra wilderness. From mountain passes to river valleys, explore state parks, historic trails, and scenic overlooks showcasing Nevada County's natural heritage.

stops.note: Historic park with trails at 12593 Donner Pass Road. Walk where the Donner Party camped through the winter of 1846-47. The 22-foot monument marks the snow depth.
stops.connector: South into the Ridge, hydraulic mining carved away mountains...

stops.note: The world's largest hydraulic mining pit at 23579 North Bloomfield Road. Trails wind through rainbow-colored cliffs — beauty born from destruction.
stops.connector: Near Grass Valley, another kind of mine...

stops.note: Historic gold mine with hiking trails at 10791 East Empire Street. 367 miles of tunnels below, miles of Sierra trails above.
stops.connector: Along the Yuba River, a different preserve...

stops.note: River park with trails at 17660 Pleasant Valley Road. Swimming holes, covered bridges, and trails along the Wild and Scenic South Yuba River.
stops.connector: In Truckee, the river flows a different direction...

stops.note: Regional park with trails at 10050 Brockway Road. The Truckee River flows east from here — to Pyramid Lake, not the Pacific.
stops.connector: The most accessible trail in the county...

stops.note: Fully accessible paved trail at 20349 Highway 49. Following an 1850s mining canal, it's one of the most beautiful wheelchair-accessible trails in California.
stops.connector: Higher in the mountains, a lake and trails...

stops.note: Lake with recreational trails at 23333 Scotts Flat Road. Swimming, fishing, camping, and trails through pine forest at 3,100 feet elevation.
stops.connector: For something more contemplative, gardens await...

stops.note: Botanical gardens with trails at 14618 Tyler Foote Road. Meditation gardens, walking paths, and Sierra foothill native plants.
stops.connector: Back in Nevada City, a downtown park...

stops.note: Downtown park with trails at 421 Nimrod Street. Where the townsfolk gather — picnics, concerts, and easy walking trails in the heart of town.
stops.connector: Grass Valley's own urban trail system...

stops.note: Urban trails system at 660 Minnie Street. Miles of trails winding through Grass Valley neighborhoods — wilderness without leaving town.

title: Family Fun Day
subtitle: Museums, Parks & Kid-Friendly Adventures
description: Perfect for adventurers of all ages. Explore hands-on museums, historic trains, scenic parks, and family dining. Create memories together while discovering Nevada County's heritage and natural wonders.

stops.note: Inside Donner Memorial State Park at 12953 Donner Pass Road. Interactive exhibits on the Donner Party and pioneer emigration. Kids love the artifacts.
stops.connector: In Grass Valley, the world's largest Pelton wheel...

stops.asset: North Star Power House & Pelton Wheel Museum
stops.note: Historic hydroelectric equipment at 933 Allison Ranch Road. The 30-foot Pelton wheel still turns — engineering marvel meets hands-on history.
stops.connector: Trains fascinate kids of all ages...

stops.note: Historic railroad artifacts at 5 Kidder Court, Nevada City. Model trains, historic equipment, and the story of the narrow gauge that connected these mountains to the world.
stops.connector: In Truckee, more railroad history awaits...

stops.note: Historic jail with interactive exhibits at 10142 Jibboom Street, Truckee. Kids can see what frontier justice looked like — and be glad those days are gone.
stops.connector: Next door, model railroads in action...

stops.note: Model railroads and exhibits at 10075 Donner Pass Road. Working model trains winding through miniature Sierra landscapes.
stops.connector: Back in Grass Valley, tools tell another story...

stops.note: The only antique tool museum in the western U.S. Kids see how things were built before power tools — and gain appreciation for their Xbox.
stops.connector: Cultural history meets family activities...

stops.note: Community cultural center with family programs and events. Check the calendar — there's usually something kid-friendly happening.
stops.connector: The Center for the Arts welcomes families...

stops.note: At 314 West Main, Grass Valley. Gallery exhibits, performances, and family-friendly arts programs. Cultivating the next generation of artists.
stops.connector: After all that culture, refuel...

stops.note: Family dining where kids are genuinely welcome. The kind of place with crayons on the table and patience at the counter.
stops.connector: For a sweet ending to the day...

stops.note: Bakery and deli perfect for families. Cookies the size of a kid's face, sandwiches to fuel the next adventure.
